授業目的:
This course analyzes the function of the Japanese legal system from the legal, sociological and political points of view. Especially the class analysis focuses upon how the cultural features influence over dispute resolution process. It begins with an introduction to the Japanese legal culture and moves on to a consideration of the relationship between legal and social ideologies and the material structures of Japanese judicial authority.
Themes basic to any of the legal literature of Japan--issues such as the nature and role of groups, the place of individuals in society, concepts of justice, gender roles, patterns of dispute resolution, and the cultural foundation of legal systems--are considered in the context of current institutional settings.
Particular attention will be paid to the interrelation between individuals and legal apparatus: how it does and does not work on the disputes in terms of the individual fundamental human rights. To understand how a specific legal rule works in legal settings in Japan, it is vital to comprehend the nature of the conflicts and internal relationships among political, legal, and administrative policies in Japan. For that purpose, this class will focus on several legal and social issues that now confront Japan.
到達目標:
1 Student will develop the knowledge of the Japanese legal system in the context of Japanese traditional culture and society.
2 Students will be able to delineate the relationships among the political, social and legal structures of the conflict resolution scheme in Japan.
3 Students will become familiar with the legal reality and function affecting the human rights, privileges, and duties of legal professions under the current legal system.

Students will be expected to have read the assigned materials before the class and prepared to respond to the questions raised in the class. Additionally, students will be expected to be ready for briefing articles and cases in the course materials and will be prepared to discuss those articles and cases.
